s1.title: Building on Windows and UNIX

s2.title: Building &XercesCName; on Windows using Microsoft Visual C++
s2.p: &XercesCName; source distribution comes with Microsoft Visual C++ projects and workspaces to help you build &XercesCName;. The following describes the steps you need to build &XercesCName;.

s3.title: Building &XercesCName; library
s3.p: To build &XercesCName; from the source distribution (using MSVC), you will need to open the workspace containing the project. If you are building your application, you may want to add the &XercesCName; project inside your application's workspace.
The workspace containing the &XercesCName; project file and all other samples is in:
Once you are inside MSVC, you need to build the project marked XercesLib.
If you want to include the &XercesCName; project separately, you need to pick up:
s3.source: (For MSVC V6) &XercesCSrcInstallDir;\Projects\Win32\VC6\xerces-all\XercesLib\XercesLib.dsp (For MSVC V7.1) &XercesCSrcInstallDir;\Projects\Win32\VC7.1\xerces-all\XercesLib\XercesLib.vcproj (For MSVC V8) &XercesCSrcInstallDir;\Projects\Win32\VC8\xerces-all\XercesLib\XercesLib.vcproj
s3.p: You must make sure that you are linking your application with the &XercesCWindowsLib;.lib library and also make sure that the associated DLL is somewhere in your path.
s3.note: If you are working on the AlphaWorks version which uses ICU, you must have the ICU data DLL named icudata.dll available from your path setting. For finding out where you can get ICU from and build it, look at the How to Build ICU.

s3.title: Building samples
s3.p: If you are using the source package, inside the same workspace (xerces-all.dsw), you'll find several other projects. These are for the samples. Select all the samples and right click on the selection. Then choose "Build (selection only)" to build all the samples in one shot.

If you are using the binary package, load the &XercesCInstallDir;-win32\samples\Projects\Win32\VC6\samples.dsw Microsoft Visual C++ workspace inside your MSVC IDE. Then select all the samples and right click on the selection. Then choose "Build (selection only)" to build all the samples in one shot.

s2.title: Building &XercesCName; 64 bit binary on Windows XP using Intel C++ Compiler
s2.p: &XercesCName; source distribution comes with Microsoft Visual C++ NMake Files which work with Intel C++ Compiler. The following describes the steps you need to build &XercesCName; 64 bit binary using Intel C++ Compiler.

s3.title: Building &XercesCName; library
s3.p: &XercesCName; source distribution provides a makefile all.mak which will build everything including samples, tests and the parser library.
s3.source: cd &XercesCSrcInstallDir;\Projects\Win32\VC6\xerces-all\all nmake -f all.mak "CFG=all - Win64 Release" CPP=ecl.exe
s3.p: If you want to just build the &XercesCName; parser library alone, then
s3.source: cd &XercesCSrcInstallDir;\Projects\Win32\VC6\xerces-all\XercesLib nmake -f XercesLib.mak "CFG=XercesLib - Win64 Release" CPP=ecl.exe
s3.p: You must make sure that you are linking your application with the &XercesCWindowsLib;.lib library and also make sure that the associated DLL is somewhere in your path.

s2.title: Building &XercesCName; on Windows using Borland C++Builder
s2.p: &XercesCName; source distribution comes with Borland C++Builder6 projects to help you build &XercesCName;. The following describes the steps you need to build &XercesCName;.

s3.title: Building &XercesCName; library
s3.p: The library and demo projects are all contained in the Xerces-all project group:
Each project in the group refers a directory below \Xerces-all. For example, the XercesLib project files are contained in the directory

To build any project, open the project manager. Double click on the project name. Then select "Project|Build" from the menu. For example, double click on XercesLib.dll in the manager. Then select "Project|Build XercesLib" from the menu.
Once the library has been built, include XercesLib.lib with in application's project and place XercesLib.dll somewhere in your path.

s2.title: Building &XercesCName; on Windows using Borland C++ Compiler
s2.p: &XercesCName; source distribution comes with Borland C++ Compiler make files to help you build &XercesCName;. The following describes the steps you need to build &XercesCName;.

s2.title: Building &XercesCName; on Windows using Cygwin

p.em: Do not jump into the build directly before reading this.

s2.p: &XercesCName; may be built in the Cygwin environment for use by Cygwin applications. As with the UNIX platforms, &XercesCName; on Cygwin uses GNU tools. Therefore, with a couple of notable exceptions, &XercesCName; on Cygwin is built using the same instructions as the UNIX platforms.

Note that Cygwin is different from the UNIX platforms in the way that it finds libraries at run time. While UNIX platforms may use the environment variable LD_LIBRARY_PATH, Cygwin uses the PATH environment variable.

There is an issue with the gcc/g++ compiler version 2.95, where C++ exceptions thrown from a dll will cause the application to crash, regardless of whether there is a "catch" statement. This bug doesn't occur in tests using gcc 3.1 or 3.2, so it is recommended that you use gcc 3.1 or higher.

s1.s2:
&XercesCName; uses GNU tools like Autoconf and GNU Make to build the system. You must first make sure you have these tools installed on your system before proceeding. If you do not have required tools, ask your system administrator to get them for you. These tools are free under the GNU Public License and may be obtained from the Free Software Foundation.
Do not jump into the build directly before reading this.
Spending some time reading the following instructions will save you a lot of wasted time and support-related e-mail communication.
Besides having all necessary build tools, you also need to know what compilers we have tested &XercesCName; on. The following table lists the relevant platforms and compilers.
&build-winunix-supported-platforms;
&build-winunix-note;
Differences between the UNIX platforms: The description below is generic, but as every programmer is aware, there are minor differences within the various UNIX flavors the world has been bestowed with. The one difference that you need to watch out in the discussion below, pertains to the system environment variable for finding libraries. On Linux and Solaris, the environment variable name is called LD_LIBRARY_PATH, on AIX it is LIBPATH, on Mac OS X it is DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH, while on HP-UX it is SHLIB_PATH. The following discussion assumes you are working on Linux, but it is with subtle understanding that you know how to interpret it for the other UNIX flavors.
If you wish to build &XercesCName; with ICU, look at the Building &XercesCName; with ICU. It tells you where you can get ICU and how to build &XercesCName; with it.
Before doing the build, you must first set your environment variables to pick-up the compiler. While the first one is probably set for you by the system administrator, just make sure you can invoke the compiler. You may do so by typing the compiler invocation command without any parameters (e.g. xlc_r, or g++, or cc) and check if you get a proper response back.
As mentioned earlier, to build &XercesCName; from the source distribution, you must be ready with the GNU tools like autoconf and gmake before you attempt the build.
The autoconf tool is required on only one platform and produces a set of portable scripts (configure) that you can run on all other platforms without actually having the autoconf tool installed everywhere. In all probability the autoconf-generated script (called configure) is already in your src/xercesc directory. If not, type:
cd <full path to &XercesCSrcInstallDir;> autoconf
This generates a shell-script called configure. It is tempting to run this script directly as is normally the case, but wait a minute. Even if you are using the default compilers like gcc and g++ you need to make some decisions about what components you want to build into the library.
You need to specify one options from each category; not specifying one will instruct configure to pick the best choice available:
Net Accessor (used to read data from HTTP sources):
--enable-netaccessor-curl Uses curl
--enable-netaccessor-libwww Uses W3C's libWWW
--enable-netaccessor-socket Uses plain BSD sockets
--enable-netaccessor-cfurl Uses cfurl (Mac-only)
--enable-netaccessor-winsock Uses WinSock (Windows-only, either Cygwin or MinGW)
Message Loader (used to store the strings of the error messages):
--enable-msgloader-inmemory Stores the messages in C++ arrays
--enable-msgloader-icu Stores the messages using ICU resource bundles
--enable-msgloader-iconv Stores the messages in a iconv message catalog
Transcoder (used to convert strings between UTF-16 and any other supported encoding):
--enable-transcoder-gnuiconv Uses GNU iconv library
--enable-transcoder-iconv Uses iconv library
--enable-transcoder-icu Uses ICU library
--enable-transcoder-macosunicodeconverter Uses MacOS APIs (Mac-only)
--enable-transcoder-windows Uses Windows APIs (Windows-only, either Cygwin or MinGW)
By default configure will build both shared and static libraries; you can use --disable-shared or --disable-static to suppress the version you don't need.
Thread support is enabled by default too; you can use --disable-threads to remove it.
If you need to specify a compiler (because more than one is found in the PATH, or because it has been renamed to a non-standard name), you should set the environment variables CXX and CC before invoking configure.
If you need special compiler or linker options, define the environment variables CXXFLAGS and LDFLAGS.
&XercesCName; can be built as either a standalone library or as a library dependent on International Components for Unicode (ICU). For simplicity, the following discussion only explains standalone builds.
The simplest way to build &XercesCName; is as follows:
./configure
This will instruct configure to find out the platform, the compiler and the libraries installed on the system. If more than one library is available for a category, the most powerful will be chosen (e.g. if ICU is available, it will be chosen over iconv).

Now that the Makefiles are all created, you are ready to do the actual build.
gmake
Is that it? Yes, that's all you need to build &XercesCName; and the associated samples.
If you need to build the tests, type
gmake check
To delete all the generated object files and executables, type:
gmake clean
